docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Doctor's Efforts to Move Practice Leaves Patients in a Tug of War'' (front page, April 8) reminded me of the satirical novel ''Dead Souls'' by Nikolai Gogol, the 19th-century Russian writer. In the novel, a swindler named Pavel Ivanovich Chichikov travels around Russia selling peasants to landowners. As it turns out, these peasants are dead, and the only thing Chichikov is peddling is a list of names.

headline.main: Patients Have a Right to Choose Their Doctors; Chichikov's List

docs.abstract: Dr Leonid Poretsky letter says tug-of-war between New York City doctor and hospital reminds him of Gogol novel in which swindler named Chichikov peddles list of names (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Managed health care plans and the Medicare program have had some success slowing growth in spending for doctors, hospitals and home care agencies. But managed care has been much less successful reining in spending on new life-enhancing medical devices and procedures. Advances in technology -- from laser treatments to the latest surgical procedures with miniature instruments -- are one of the main reasons for the reacceleration in the overall costs of health insurance, after several years of slow or zero growth. Sales of new medical devices in the United States rose 30 percent over the last five years, outpacing the 22 percent rise over all in health care spending and all other categories except prescription drug sales, which were up 50 percent.

headline.main: A New Strain On the Cost Of Health Care; Latest Medical Devices Bring Bigger Bills

docs.abstract: Advances in technology are one of main reasons for reacceleration in overall costs of health insurance, after several years of slow or zero growth; sales of new medical devices in US rose 30 percent over last five years, outpacing 22 percent rise over all in health care spending and all other categories, except prescription drug sales, which were up 50 percent; some new medical devices described; chart; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Managed health care plans and the Medicare program have had some success slowing growth in spending for doctors, hospitals and home care agencies. But managed care has been much less successful reining in spending on new life-enhancing medical...

docs.lead_paragraph: Trade officials from the United States and China are scrounging for a deal that would allow President Clinton and Prime Minister Zhu Rongji to announce today that the two countries have come to agreement on China's application to join the World Trade Organization. If the issue were narrowly about trade and economics, the two sides would probably have little trouble shaking hands. China, one of the world's major trading powers, wants membership in the organization that sets and adjudicates the rules. The Clinton Administration thinks that is just fine -- as long as China agrees to open its borders widely to imports and foreign investors. There is plenty of economic room for a deal.

headline.main: Economic Scene: Limits of Economic Diplomacy; Modest Goals in Push to Bring China Into Trade Group

docs.abstract: Economic Scene column on economic and political issues surrounding China's desire to enter World Trade Organization as China's Prime Min Zhu Rongji begins US visit; says Pres Clinton and Zhu are hemmed in by politics; Clinton must look over his shoulders at Republicans who want no accord at all and Democrats who want deal to satisfy every one of their constituencies; holds Zhu faces domestic problems from those within Communist Party who are not enthusiastic about market reforms and from managers and workers who risk losing their jobs; benefits and drawbacks of China's entrance into WTO for US and China detailed; graphs; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Trade officials from the United States and China are scrounging for a deal that would allow President Clinton and Prime Minister Zhu Rongji to announce today that the two countries have come to agreement on China's application to join the World Trade...

docs.lead_paragraph: It happens all the time in the legal and financial world: lawyers or stockbrokers jump from one firm to another, taking their clients -- and the clients' money -- with them. But what happens if the professional is a doctor? When Dr. Andrew Wiznia, a highly regarded pediatric AIDS specialist at Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center, announced in February that he would move to another Bronx hospital, Jacobi Medical Center, followed by his patients and precious Medicaid and research-grant money, the hospital wasted no time: it sued him and two colleagues, asking not only for millions of dollars in damages but seeking to bar the doctors from treating their patients anywhere else for six months.

headline.main: Doctor's Effort to Move Practice Leaves Patients in a Tug of War

docs.abstract: Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center sues Dr Andrew Wiznia, highly regarded pediatric AIDS specialist, for seeking to move to another Bronx hospital, Jacobi Medical Center; Bronx-Lebanon contends that patients in pediatric AIDS center belong to hospital; it has warned AIDS clinic's workers against offering patients 'choices' about where they can be treated; such high-stakes turf wars are becoming more common among hospitals around country as managed care squeezes hospitals' budgets; hospitals are wooing popular doctors, hoping they will bring rich pipeline of patients and coveted research grant money; biggest battles are over particularly coveted set of Medicaid patients, those whose bills are richly reimbursed, like Wiznia's patients; health care experts say Wiznia case is unusual because hospital has actually gone to court to block his move; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: DuPont said yesterday that it would invest $220 million in an Internet health care program with WebMD Inc. WebMD, which began in October, offers doctors and consumers information about medicine and managed care. The deal will help DuPont, the nation's largest chemical company, increase its life-sciences business. Last month DuPont said it would issue a new class of stock to track the performance of the business; it also plans to expand the unit through alliances and acquisitions.

headline.main: DUPONT TO INVEST $220 MILLION IN ALLIANCE WITH WEBMD

docs.lead_paragraph: In a sign of intensifying opposition to Attorney General Peter G. Verniero's appointment to the New Jersey Supreme Court, the Legislature's top Democrat yesterday released a study of the qualifications of every justice named to the bench during the last half-century and said it raised ''troubling questions'' about whether Mr. Verniero had the judicial background or legal expertise to merit confirmation. Speaking at a news conference in the New Jersey State House, the Senate minority leader, Richard Codey, Democrat of Essex, said that Mr. Verniero had far more political credentials than legal experience, because he never served as a judge and worked just five years in private practice before beginning his rise through the state Republican Party.

headline.main: Key Democrat Faults Choice For Top Court In New Jersey

docs.abstract: New Jersey Senate minority leader Richard Codey, in sign of intensifying opposition to Atty Gen Peter G Verniero's appointment to State Supreme Court, releases study of qualifications of every justice named to bench during last 50 years and says it raises 'troubling questions' about whether Verniero has judicial background or legal expertise to merit confirmation; says Verniero has far more political credentials than legal experience, because he never served as judge and worked just five years as lawyer in private practice; Verniero photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 500 members of New York City's largest janitors' union held 10 demonstrations in Manhattan and Brooklyn yesterday to protest a growing practice in which building managers hire contractors who pay their janitors far less than the union's rate. The protests by Local 32B-32J of the Service Employees International Union focused on Golden Mark Maintenance, a cleaning company that union officials said does not provide health insurance and pays its workers about half the $14 an hour earned by the local's janitors.

headline.main: Janitors Stage Protests Over Wage-Cutting Contractors

docs.lead_paragraph: The New York State Department of Insurance announced yesterday that it has fined 14 insurance companies for failure to pay claims within 45 days of receiving them. Oxford Health Plans of New York, received the highest fine, $51,000. Aetna U.S. Healthcare was fined $31,900, Vytra Health Plans was fined $8,300 and H.I.P. was fined $7,100. Ten other health insurance companies were fined a total of $16,600, the Department of Insurance said.
docs.abstract: New York State Insurance Dept fines 14 health insurance companies for failure to pay claims within 45 days of receiving them; Oxford Health Plans of New York receives highest fine, $51,000 (S)
